channel.title: Dandenong Ranges Coleoptera
channel.description: All beetles, their eggs or larvae found in the Dandenong Ranges area which includes the area from Police Paddocks to Upper Beaconsfield to Cockatoo to Mt Evelyn.

item.title: Unidentified
item.dc:creator: leuba
item.description:
A small, very active dark beetle commonly called Water Penny from family Psephenidae had a slightly dorso-ventrally flattened body. The elytra showed two narrow bands of pale specks. The pronotum which was the same colour as the elytra had a pair of short pale streaks on either side of midline arising from the posterior margin. The lateral margins had pale flecks. The elytra stopped short of the terminal abdominal segments. Head was small with relatively large closely placed eyes. Antennae were segmented. Legs were thin with feeble tarsi. Flew in towards the garden lights on a warm night and then disappeared under some wood.
( Please add Sclerocyphon sp.)

item.title: Methypora postica
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: An unusual tiny weevil with a frayed abdomen which seemed to mimic a broken twig. It wouldn't move when touched but remained in a face-down and rear-up posture. About 6mm long.

item.title: Arsipoda montana
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: About 10mm long. I haven't seen a colourful Flea-leaf beetle before. Most Alticini are black/blue. No idea what the other creature is.

item.title: Pterohelaeus spp.
item.dc:creator: leuba
item.description: This dusty blue beetle was about 13 mm long. The dorso-ventrally flattened body had a flange around both the thorax and elytra. Spotted under bright lights in a suburban garden on a very warm night. This could be P.peltatus but needs confirmation.

item.title: Castiarina octomaculata
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Found on leptospermum flowers in Churchill NP This one has blue legs and underside - unlike most others of the species.

item.title: Harmonia conformis
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Eggs of the 22 spotted ladybird, Harmonia conformis The layer left the scene just as we turned up.

item.title: Hesthesis spp.
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: A large longicorn which looks very similar to the larger flower wasps (Tiphiidae;Thynnus) around at the same time. Genus is known for very diminished elytra. About 30mm body. Hesthesis spp. (likely H.plorator) https://apps2.cdfa.ca.gov/publicApps/plant/bycidDB/wdetails.asp?id=20106&w=o

item.title: Amphirhoe decora
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Feeding on leptospermum flowers in Churchill NP

item.title: Parablax spp.
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: About 25mm long.. Parablax sp. but not sure which one.

item.title: Calosoma (Australodrepa) schayeri
item.dc:creator: leuba
item.description:
This 20 mm long beetle looked very different to other ground beetles because of its flattened body and a thorax that is notched both anteriorly and posteriorly. Elytra showed fine parallel ridges and had a metallic sheen which reflected purple and teal colours. Legs were long had short spines.
These ground beetles are said to feed on caterpillars. They are strongly attracted to U-V emitting lights and can congregate in large numbers but do not stay in one place for long. They stay hidden during the day but are very active at night.

item.title: Pterohelaeus spp.
item.dc:creator: leuba
item.description: About 12 mm long this black beetle had broadly convex body with ridged elytra and a thin marginal flange. The pronotum showed broader flanges and thick lateral margins. Head and eyes were small. Antennae had beaded segments. Spotted on grass in a park.

item.title: Cerambycidae spp.
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: About 22mm body length. These were common on the day but I haven't seen them before or since. Yet to search for species...

item.title: Neorrhina punctatum
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: About 18mm long, Thick white setae underneath. Flower chafer. Unusual to find in leaf litter; usually working over flowers.

item.title: Rhynolaccus spp.
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Tiny 3-4mm ant mimic weevil all shiny black. On Acacia dealbata.

item.title: Euops spp.
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: A small (5mm) weevil which has created a nidus. The relationships here are extraordinary. The female weevil steps out a measure of leaf, cuts it, folds and rolls it smearing a mystery substance as she goes, and injecting spores of a penicillin fungus she had collected in thoracic cavities. The peniciliin protects the larvae as they develop from other infections but don't provide nourishment. Family Attelabidae; Genus Euops: need to add these

item.title: Scarabaeidae spp.
item.dc:creator: leuba
item.description: This beetle was about 22 mm long, robust with dark head and thorax and purplish brown elytra. Antennal ends were lamellate. Dense golden setae on the underside.

item.title: Carabidae spp., Sarothrocrepis civica
item.dc:creator: leuba
item.description: A small black beetle about 5 mm long with glossy black elytra with pale patches at the base. The elytra appeared to stop short of the last few abdominal segments. The scape of antennae were a pale brown and appeared to have a short spine. Subfamily: Lebiinae Thanks to Chris Lindorff for helping with identifying the beetle.

item.title: Chrysomelidae spp.
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Cryptocephalinae->Aporocera ?? About 10mm long. Under lights on a vehicle at the DNRP.

item.title: Paropsis charybdis
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: A large (14mm) leaf beetle attracted to lights at the edge of the local national park. Looks similar to Paropsis charybdis but there are 2 large dark patches to be explained first. To discuss with Martin Lagerwey.

item.title: Rodatus spp.
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: This ladybird larva shocked me with it's size. Estimated 20mm. Found on the trunk of a large, broad leaf acacia upon which there was also a giant scale bug (Monophlebulus sp). Predator & prey?

item.title: Omorgus spp.
item.dc:creator: leuba
item.description: A heavily sclerotised Hide Beetle with ridged and sculptured elytra and thorax. It was a dusty brown and about 12 mm in length. The head was deflexed and it was difficult to see any details except briefly. Short segmented antennae ended in a three segmented club.

item.title: Paropsisterna spp.
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: A large paropsid leaf beetle (15mm length) which looked fully black to the eye but the flash has revealed a set of full length, deep red lines. No dents were noticed on or around the pronotum. I have always found these at night so suspect they hide in daytime maybe under bark.

item.title: Hippodamia variegata
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Here's mud in your eye! Small numbers of these were on the few remaining 'weeds' after an area was extensively slashed. About 12mm long. Patterns on elytra seemed to vary.

item.title: Paropsisterna variicollis
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Gold coloured with tint of orange. Light striations and shallow pits in lines. About 10mm long. Some black exposed when head is flexed. Local nature reserve. Kings Park.

item.title: Castiarina sexguttata
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is Castiarina sexguttata, a small yellow jewel beetle with six or four or two or no green dots on the elytra.

item.title: Castiarina octomaculata
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: The size and colour resembles an elongated ladybird. About 18mm long. On Leptospermum scoparia in a local national park. Ladybird mimic Jewel beetle (♀)?.

item.title: Castiarina rectifasciata
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: About 18mm long. Feeding on Leptospermum scoparium flowers. In a local national park.

item.title: Castiarina erythroptera
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: About 18mm long. Feeding on Leptospermum scoparium flowers. In a local national park. This one is part of a ring of Batesian mimicry.

item.title: Castiarina cruentata
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: A colorful jewel beetle about 15mm long. Deep metallic blue including ventral parts and legs but with two and a half pairs of deep orange, broken bands over the wing cases. Feeding on Leptosperma scoparium in a local nature reserve.

item.title: Castiarina flavopicta
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: This jewel beetle was a little more elusive than most possibly as it was about half the size of most of the others it could bury itself into the flowers more easily. Estimated 11mm long and the yellow loops were in two shades. On Leptospermum scoparium in a local nature reserve.

item.title: Castiarina scalaris
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Jewel beetle found on ti-tree flowers. This one a little larger than most at about 15mm. On Leptospermum scoparium in a local nature reserve.

item.title: Castiarina punctatosulcata
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: About 14mm long. Feeding on various flowers including a Daucus-like plant and some large Asteraceae. In a local nature reserve.

item.title: Castiarina sexplagiata
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: About 18mm long.. male slightly smaller than female.. feeding (among other things) on Leptospermum scoparium flowers. In a local national park.

item.title: Distichocera fuliginosa
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: This beetle was exploring the stem of a small Kunzea shrub and, after some time, it stopped and began to 'wriggle'. She was laying reddish coloured eggs into a fault in the skin of the plant. About 40mm long body. This specimen with one red antenna and one mostly black. In a nature reserve adjacent to a large man-made reservoir. The male of this species is smaller and has very 'feathery' (lamellate) antennae.

item.title: Enchoptera spp.
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Body length about 25mm. Very long scape on antennae. Feeding on the flowers of a small tree (Bentham's Cornel - Cornus capitata) in a local reserve. Most likely 'Enchoptera apicalis'.

item.title: Lamprima aurata
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: These can vary from copper-gold to a deep blue colour. This one a green-blue female. About 25mm long overall and just clinging to the topmost part of a small spiny acacia. In a local nature reserve. Glenfern Valley Reserve.

item.title: Obrida fascialis
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: About 12mm long body. Initially I thought a type of jewel beetle but later showed Cerambycid features. Antennae show white bands towards the outer ends. Four front orange femurs two rear black. Hiding in the dried remains of flowers (peeled away) on a shrub yet to be identified. Similar to Pittosporum? Police Paddocks.

item.title: Mordellidae spp.
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: Possibly the largest Mordellidae I have seen so far estimated at about 16mm long overall. Feeding on flowers of leptospermum and kunzea. Wicks nature reserve.

item.title: Cryptolaemus montrouzieri
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: A ladybug larva that resembles a white nudibranch and is a voracious scale bug eater. About 12mm long at this stage. Exploring the outer branches of an Acacia mearnsii. One of about a dozen. In a local nature reserve. Gilmour Park.

item.title: Tarsostenodes simulator
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: A small clerid beetle moving and marked like an ant. About 12mm long. Dark red antennae and legs. Cleridae, Clerinae, Scrobiger seems most likely and this is not the one with yellow antennae. This might be the target of mimicry found in the same area http://natureshare.org.au/observations/54f7c4c3ed2a89097e00027d

item.title: Calosoma (Australodrepa) schayeri
item.dc:creator: argybee
item.description: 25mm long. Metallic green elytra and head and metallic red pronotum. Attracted to activity or lights at night at the local school yard.
